translated: Basket of Conduct
The Chapter on the Elephant King
The Perfection of Morality
The Story of the Untimidating Being
“In the excellent city of the kingdom of Pañcāla,
in the supreme city of Kapila,
there was a king named Jayaddisa,
who had attained the virtue of morality.
I was the son of that king,
learned in the Dhamma, of good morality;
I was an untimidating being with good qualities,
always protected by my retinue.
My father went hunting
and approached a bandit;
he seized my father
and said, ‘You’re my food, don’t move.’

analyzed: tassa tam vacanam sutvā  bhītaḥ tasita vedhitaḥ
translated: Having heard his words,🔽frightened, trembling, and terrified,
I became his support,
seeing the bandit.
‘Release the hunter and let him go,
after making him return;
Having given wealth to the brahmin,
my father summoned me.
‘Son, take over the kingdom,
don’t neglect this city;
I’ve made an agreement with the bandit
for my return.’
Having paid homage to my parents,
and having created myself,
having laid aside my bow and sword,
I approached the bandit.
If he were to fall from the tree,
he might be killed by the weapon.
My virtue would be broken,
if I were to save myself.
Through fear of breaking my virtue,
I did not tell him what I thought.
With a mind of loving-kindness, speaking for his welfare,🔽I spoke these words:
‘Light a great fire,
I will jump from the tree.
When you know that I am cooked,
eat me, O Grandfather.’
Thus, for the sake of my virtue,
I did not protect my life.
I gave him the going-forth,
that killer of living beings.”
The Story of the Non-violent Being is the ninth.
